trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure a connection string to an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure a connection string to an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: A connection string includes the information needed to authenticate programmatic access to resources in a storage account.
trans-unit.target: A connection string includes the information needed to authenticate programmatic access to resources in a storage account.

trans-unit.source: The connection string may encapsulate your account access key for an account that you own, or it may include a shared access signature for accessing resources in an account without the access key.
trans-unit.target: The connection string may encapsulate your account access key for an account that you own, or it may include a shared access signature for accessing resources in an account without the access key.

trans-unit.source: Your application uses the connection string to provide to Azure Storage the information needed to authenticate access.

trans-unit.source: Storing your connection string
trans-unit.target: Storing your connection string

trans-unit.source: Your application will need to store the connection string in order to authenticate access to Azure Storage when it is running.
trans-unit.target: Your application will need to store the connection string in order to authenticate access to Azure Storage when it is running.

trans-unit.source: You have a few different options for storing your connection string:
trans-unit.target: You have a few different options for storing your connection string:

trans-unit.source: For an application running on the desktop or on a device, you can store the connection string in an app.config file or another configuration file.
trans-unit.target: For an application running on the desktop or on a device, you can store the connection string in an app.config file or another configuration file.

trans-unit.source: If you are using an app.config file, add the connection string to the **AppSettings** section.
trans-unit.target: If you are using an app.config file, add the connection string to the **AppSettings** section.

trans-unit.source: For an application running in an Azure cloud service, you can store your connection string in the [Azure service configuration schema (.cscfg) file](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee758710.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For an application running in an Azure cloud service, you can store your connection string in the [Azure service configuration schema (.cscfg) file](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee758710.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Add the connection string to the **ConfigurationSettings** section of the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Add the connection string to the **ConfigurationSettings** section of the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Storing your connection string within a configuration file makes it easy to update the connection string to switch between the storage emulator and an Azure storage account in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Storing your connection string within a configuration file makes it easy to update the connection string to switch between the storage emulator and an Azure storage account in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: You only need to edit the connection string to point to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: You only need to edit the connection string to point to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure [CloudConfigurationManager](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.cloudconfigurationmanager.aspx) class to access your connection string at runtime regardless of where your application is running.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure [CloudConfigurationManager](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.cloudconfigurationmanager.aspx) class to access your connection string at runtime regardless of where your application is running.
